choices.text: Serum levels of IgG, IgM, IgA, IgE
A complete blood count with differential

questions.text: Of the following options, the best initial test for a workup for immunodeficiency is
questions.solution:
• The initial step in the workup of a child with a suspected immunodeficiency should always include a complete blood count and differential, as this test will reveal disorders involving lymphopenia (particularly T-cell lymphopenias) and neutropenia. Other hints can be found by the CBC, including small platelets associated with the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, anemias, and evidence of eosinophilia.
  • An erythrocyte sedimentation rate is a nonspecific marker of inflammation and would not point to a specific immunodeficiency. (option d)
  • While quantitative immunoglobulins, peripheral T-cell phenotyping, and lack of antibody response to standard immunizations would all be part of an immunodeficiency investigation, these would not be considered first steps in the evaluation. (option a, c)

questions.text: The following are causes of neutropenia except:
questions.solution:
Causes of Neutropenia (Immune related)

  • Schwachman-Diamond syndrome
  • Glycogen storage disease type 1b
  • Dyskeratosis congenita
  • Severe combined immune deficiency
  • Chediak-Higashi syndrome
  • Chronic benign neutropenia
  • Preleukemia syndrome

choices.text: A complete blood cell counts with differential

questions.text: A 7-day-old female newborn had an abnormal result on newborn screening revealing an absence of T-cell receptor excision circles (TREC), which raises concern regarding severe combined immunodeficiency. Of the following, the MOST appropriate next test to confirm the diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Severe combined immunodeficiency represents a group of genetic primary immunodeficiencies defined by dysfunction of humoral and cell mediated immunity.
  • The definitive test for quantifying lymphocyte subsets is flow cytometry.
  • Left untreated, children with severe combined immunodeficiency die early in life owing to infection, but the condition is curable with allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant.

choices.text: It is inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder
It is associated with microthrombocytopenia, eczema and immunodeficiency
Intrinsic abnormalities of B-cell function are a common feature
Low levels of IgM and increased levels of IgA, IgD and IgE can found

questions.text: The following statements are true with regard to Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome except:
questions.solution:
• This is inherited as an X-linked recessive disease and defect in WASP gene.
  • It is usually characterized by immune dysregulation (immune deficiency, eczema or autoimmunity) and microthrombocytopenia.
  • They have triad of eczema, recurrent infections and (option b)
  • The platelets are small, and it can present with minor bruising as well as life-threatening GIT or intracranial bleeding.
  • WAS is associated with low levels of IgM and increased levels of IgA, IgD and IgE, due to dysfunctional B cells. (option c, d)
  • Using prophylactic antibiotics and immunoglobulin for infection is the conventional therapy. Splenectomy is usually effective in increasing platelet numbers and reducing bleeding complications, but also increases the risk of infection. Stem cell transplantation is curative and gene therapy may help in the future.
  • Major complications associated with WAS include autoimmune phenomena, including hematological cytopenia, small- and large-vessel vasculitis, lymphoproliferative disease, and lymphoma.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent UTI and chest infection. The mother recalls that umbilical cord separation occurred at the age of 3 weeks. He suffered from a skin infection, which required admission for IV antibiotics for 2 weeks and plastic surgery on his left shoulder. Neutrophil and monocyte adherence, aggregation and chemotaxis, and phagocytosis demonstrate abnormalities. Autoantibodies and response to vaccination are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis of the child?
questions.solution:
• This is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It is not associated with defects in lymphocyte or antibody function.
  • As mentioned in the question, the wounds take long time to heal as the neutrophil cannot reach the infection sites. Also, as there are no leukocytes at the site, there is no pus formation- they are dry wounds.

REMEMBER- 'Delayed cord fall' must be looked for in the question as a spotter- highly likely to be LAD and among LAD mostly LAD I

choices.text: Delaying this vaccine increases the risk of the complication of rotaviral diarrheas
Only 1 dose of the vaccine should be administered
The 2-dose series is preferred over the 3-dose series of the vaccine, given the family history
This vaccine is contraindicated, given the family history

questions.text: A 2-month-old male infant is brought to your office for a health supervision visit. When discussing vaccines, his mother reports that her daughter had an intussusception that was reduced by the radiologist. She would like to delay administration of the rotavirus vaccine for her son until 6 months of age. Of the following, considering his sibling's history, the MOST accurate information you can provide is that for this infant
questions.solution:
• Rotavirus vaccine, an orally administered, live vaccine that is highly effective at preventing gastroenteritis caused by rotavirus, should be administered routinely at 6, 10, 14 weeks of age.
  • There are age limits beyond which the vaccine should not be administered (14 weeks, 6 days for a first dose; 8 months, 0 days for the second or third doses); thus, delaying the vaccine could result in missed opportunities for protection.
  • There is a small, increased risk of intussusception with the first dose of the rotavirus vaccine, which has an acceptable risk-benefit ratio within the permitted age range.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented to your clinic with recurrent subcutaneous abscesses, lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, and family history of recurrent granulomatous infections, you suspected chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). The diagnosis is confirmed by which of the following methods?
questions.solution:
• CGD is an immune disorder where there is decreased NADPH dependent, free oxygen radicle production needed for killing catalase positive organisms.
  • The diagnosis is most often made by performing flow cytometry using dihydrorhodamine 123 (DHR) to measure oxidant production through its increased fluorescence when oxidized by H2O2.

choices.text: 1 dose of PCV13 followed by 1 dose of PPSV23 at least 8 weeks later
1 dose of PPSV23 followed by 1 dose of PCV13 at least 8 weeks later
2 doses of PCV13, 4 weeks apart, followed by 1 dose of PPSV23 at least 8 weeks later
2 doses of PPSV23, 4 weeks apart, followed by 1 dose of PCV13 at least 8 weeks later

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy adolescent end-stage renal disease who is scheduled to undergo related-donor renal transplantation in 3 months is undergoing a review of his immunization status. He has received all age-appropriate immunizations, including 4 doses of 7-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV7). He has not received any doses of 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) or 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23). Of the following, the MOST appropriate next step for this patient is to administer
questions.solution:
• Pediatric solid organ transplant recipients are at increased risk of acquiring invasive pneumococcal disease compared with the general population.
  • In children aged 6 through 18 years at high risk of pneumococcal disease who have not received any doses of PCV13 or PPSV23, administration of 1 dose of PCV13 followed by 1 dose of PPSV23 at least 8 weeks later and a second dose of PPSV23 5 years after the first is recommended.

choices.text: IgG2 deficiency is associated with low IgA
IgG2 deficiency is associated with poor antibody responses to encapsulated organisms
IgG3 is associated with increased viral infections

questions.text: IgG subclass deficiency is associated with the following except:
questions.solution:
• This is a very rare condition that sometimes may be responsible for primary severe immune deficiency. Children usually present with upper respiratory tract infection.
  • It can be familial, and repeated infection may cause bronchiectasis.
  • IgG2 deficiency is associated with decreased IgA levels
  • IgG1 deficiency increases risk of Tetanus and diphtheria
  • IgG2 deficiency increases risk of infections by encapsulated organisms
  • IgG3 deficiency increases risk of Viral infections
  • IgG4 deficiency increases risk of parasitic infections
  • It usually resolves spontaneously, and immunoglobulin is not needed except in cases with severe recurrent infection.
  • Prophylactic azithromycin or Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is advisable. No routine blood tests or chest X-rays are needed.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy presents with second lobar pneumonia over the last 3 months. The level of all immunoglobulins is low, and the tonsils are hypoplastic as are the adenoids. Peripheral blood B lymphocytes are absent. Most likely immune pathology?
questions.solution:
• This affects males, with a repeated history of bacterial infection. It usually occurs after 6 months of age and before 2 years of age.
  • The most frequent sites of infection are otitis, sinusitis and pneumonia, (Respiratory system) and the most common organisms are Hemophilus influenzae and Streptococcus pneumoniae. (encapsulated).
  • All isotypes of immunoglobulins are absent or very low. Circulating mature B cells are absent, as are specific antibodies. T cells are normal. Arrest occurs at maturation of Pre-B cells.
  • The treatment is lifelong immunoglobulin replacement every 6-8 weeks and maintenance of IgG. Infections should be treated, and physiotherapy should be given for bronchiectasis.

SPOTTERS- All Ig Low, Absent B cells, Normal T cells

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl visits you with purpose of HPV vaccination. What is the advised schedule for HPV 4 vaccination in this patient?
questions.solution:
IAP recommendations for HPV 4

  • 9-14 years - 2 doses at 0, 6 months
  • 15-45 years - 3 doses at 0, 2, 6 months

questions.text: A 12-month-old male child is brought to your office for a well-child examination and immunizations. You have been following the child since delivery and are aware that he has acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) and a Markedly reduced CD4 count (~10%). Which of the following vaccinations should he not receive?
questions.solution:
• All the vaccines mentioned, except varicella, are killed or synthetic vaccines.
  • Live virus vaccines are contraindicated in the case of AIDS with a markedly reduced T-cell count. The IPV is the inactivated version of the live polio vaccine, oral polio vaccine (OPV).
  • Live attenuated vaccine includes
    • Oral polio vaccine
    • Measles, Mumps, Rubella
    • Influenza
    • BCG
    • Rotavirus
    • Epidemic typhus
    • JE
    • Oral typhoid
    • Yellow fever
    • Plague

Both killed and live available

LATEST UPDATE ON LIVE VACCINE & HIV POSITIVES

In all Asymptomatic AIDS patients, ALL LIVE VACCINES can be given EXCEPT OPV

choices.text: Special focus on Measles and Rubella vaccination
Jan Pratinidhi and social media influencers were involved
U-WIN application has been integrated with UIP

questions.text: Select the incorrect statement pertaining to Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) 5.0
questions.solution:
KEY FACTS ABOUT IMI 5.0

  • Over and above the routine immunizations, special focus is to increase coverage of Measles and Rubella immunization. (option a)
  • Targeted population are children <5 years and Pregnant women (was <2 years with MI 4.0)
  • U-WIN platform initiated for COVID vaccination has been integrated with UIP for digital documentation of routine immunization. (option d)
  • Participation from Jan Pratinidhi and social media influencers across states have come forward to appeal to public to visit nearest vaccination center and take the missed doses. (option c)

Reference: Ministry of Health and family welfare press release, Oct 23

choices.text: Can be used for next 1 hour
Can be used till inner square is lighter than outer circle
Depends on the availability of vaccines

questions.text: You are giving vaccine in your OPD and observe following color of VVM in OPV vaccine. What is the next course of action?

A 2-day-old baby boy is admitted at the neonatal intensive care unit due to high fever with a temperature of 38°C and seizures. Physical examination reveals a newborn baby with wide-set eyes, small mandible, and a cleft palate. On auscultation of the heart, there is a holosystolic ejection murmur at the fourth intercostal space in the midclavicular line. Serum chemistries show severe hypocalcemia. This syndrome is caused by mutant genes found in which of the following chromosomes?
questions.solution:
• The boy presents with common manifestations of DiGeorge syndrome.
  • Its pathophysiology involves microdeletions of specific DNA sequences, called the DiGeorge chromosomal region (DGCR), from chromosome 22q11.2.
  • It is often called the CATCH22 syndrome because of its characteristic manifestations.
  • DiGeorge syndrome has characteristic features which include

Cardiac abnormalities - Interrupted aortic arch, Truncus arteriosus, Tetralogy of Fallot

Abnormal facies - Hypertelorism, Anti mongoloid slant, Folded ears, abnormal philtrum, thin upper lip, Mandibular hypoplasia

Thymic hypoplasia,

Cleft palate,

Hypocalcemia.

  • Patients with partial DiGeorge syndrome may grow normally but patients who have complete DiGeorge syndrome have a very low immunity and increased susceptibility to infections even with common pathogens.
  • Timely diagnosis is critical since the disease is fatal without treatment.
